title: Hap Python Remote Debugger
desc: A remote debugger and IDE that can also be used for local debugging.

title: IPython
desc: An enhanced interactive Python shell with many features for object introspection, system shell access, and its own special command system for adding functionality when working interactively. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: PyCrust - The Flakiest Python Shell
desc: An interactive, graphical Python shell written in Python using wxPython.

title: Pymerase
desc: A tool intended to generate a python object model, relational database, and an object-relational model connecting the two using UML or XML. However, it has been extended to also output GUI widgets and can be easily extended to output whatever else you might like. [Open source, MIT License]

title: PyReverse
desc: A set of tools for reverse engineering Python code, including creation of files readable by ArgoUML. Project information, downloads, and bug-track details. [Open Source, GPL]

title: Tixapps Applications Framework
desc: Tixapps applications are a suite of development applications that run with  Tk/Tcl or Python, using the Tix widget set. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: Winpdb
desc: An advanced python debugger, with support for smart breakpoints, multiple threads, namespace modification, embedded debugging and encrypted communication.

title: BayPIGgies
desc: The Silicon Valley-San Francisco Bay Area Python Users Group.

title: Chicago Python User Group
desc: Meetings, book reviews and mailing list.

title: Clepy
desc: A group of Python enthusiasts living in the Cleveland, Ohio, area.

title: Dallas Ft. Worth Pythoneers
desc: Offers mailing list, a source repository and member profiles.

title: Fredericksburg ZPUG
desc: Fredericksburg Zope and Python Users Group.

title: FRPythoneers
desc: A Python user group in the Fort Collins area that meets in Broomfield, CO.

title: The GrimPypers
desc: A group of Python users, programmers and enthusiasts based in Grimstad, Norway.

title: Michipug
desc: Michigan (Detroit/Ann Arbor) Python group.

title: Omaha Python Users Group
desc: A Python users group in the Omaha, NE Metro area.

title: OPAG
desc: Ottawa Python Authors Group. A group devoted to learning, using and providing resources for Python. OPAG also serves as a general gathering place for Python programmers from the Ottawa region and beyond.

title: PyAtl
desc: Atlanta, Georgia Python User Group.

title: PyGTA
desc: The Toronto Python/Zope User Group meets regularly to explore the expanding world of Python and Zope.

title: SeaPig
desc: The Seattle Python Interest Group.

title: TriZPUG
desc: he Triangle Zope/Python User Group in the Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill area of North Carolina, USA.

title: Utah Python User Group
desc: Offers meeting information, mailing list and links to members' blogs.

title: eff-bot's Daily Python URL
desc: Contains links to assorted resources from the Python universe, compiled by PythonWare.

title: O'Reilly Python Center
desc: Features Python books, resources, news and articles.

title: Python Developer's Guide
desc: Resources for reporting bugs, accessing the Python source tree with CVS and taking part in the development of Python.

title: Social Bug
desc: Scripts, examples and news about Python programming for the Windows platform.

title: Altis, Kevin
desc: News and information related to Python and its promotion as "most powerful language you can still read."

title: Anand Pillai -  Random bytes on technology and open source
desc: A Python programmer's weblog.

title: Blended Technologies
desc: Programming weblog for a small, newly formed, and curious company; covers mostly Python.

title: Gruet, Richard
desc: Python Language Quick Reference versions 1.5 to 2.3. OmniORBpy utilities and other Python stuff.

title: Hinsen, Konrad
desc: Python for science. In particular computational chemistry.

title: Kuchling, A.M.
desc: Lots of Python code and information, several quotation collections, and a Robertson Davies page.

title: Learning Python
desc: A weblog tracking one man's journey into Python.

title: Lundh, Fredrik
desc: Personal guide to libraries, modules and extensions. Includes a weblog with Python news and personal ramblings.

title: Norlanders, Oscar
desc: Blog about programming. TeX bibliography tweak. Resume. Links.

title: van Rossum, Guido
desc: Personal home page of the creator of the Python programming language.

title: Python Documentation Index
desc: Official tutorial and references, including library/module usage, Macintosh libraries, language syntax, extending/embedding, and the Python/C API. Also links to off-site beginners' tutorials, HOWTOs, and many special interest topics.

title: About.com: Python
desc: Includes articles on simple script solutions, database management, web development, network protocols, and other advanced topics.

title: A Beginner's Python Tutorial
desc: A Python tutorial originally written for the modding community of Firaxis' Civilization. Useful to beginners with little or no programming knowledge.

title: Cameron Laird on Python and the Web
desc: Discusses both client-side and server-side Web programming.

title: Code Like a Pythonista: Idiomatic Python
desc: A tutorial that teaches common Python programming idioms used by experienced programmers, but may not be obvious to newcomers.

title: A Course in Python/CGI
desc: This site contains materials from a 13 week course for learning Python and CGI. Suited for self-study.

title: The Django Book
desc: Free (Only E-Book version) Django Web Framework E-Book by APress. The best book for learning Django. Requires good understanding of Python.

title: Five Minutes to a Python CGI
desc: By David Mertz. Brief introduction to writing CGI programs, Python CGI module, formatting output, error logging/debugging.

title: Instant Hacking
desc: By Magnus Lie Hetland. Minimal, concise, general introduction to programming, via Python, moves very quickly. English, Italian, Polish, Japanese, Serbian, Korean.

title: Instant Python
desc: By Magnus Lie Hetland. Minimal introduction for experienced programmers. Treats basics, OO programming, Jedi mind trick. English, French, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish; German, Norwegian; Lithuanian, Polish, Russian; Japanese, Korean.

title: One Day of IDLE Toying
desc: By Danny Yoo. Visual guide to using IDLE, a simple interactive shell for Python programming. Each step of this tutorial has screenshots for absolute beginners. English, Dutch, German; Greek, French, Italian, Portuguese; Indonesian.

title: Python and UML
desc: Can the UML help Python developers? How about CP4E?

title: Python CGI
desc: An Interactive Instruction.

title: Python Database Programming
desc: Programs can use minimal code to access, display, and update a database. This guide provides "links to relevant Python modules, documentation, and projects" concerning databases, as well as adding persistence to Python objects.

title: Python for Beginners
desc: New to programming? This page lists some places that can get you started quickly.

title: Python Programming for Beginners
desc: Shows how to write programs that use command-line options, read and write to pipes, access environment variables, handle interrupts, read from and write to files, create temporary files, write to system logs.

title: Python Programming Tutorial
desc: By Richard G. Baldwin. Separate lessons teach programming basics. Free online, fee download files.

title: Python Quick Reference
desc: By Simon Brunning. Thorough 'cheat sheet'; brief reminders for nearly each language aspect: syntax nuances; built-in features, statements, modules; basic, advanced types, operations; lexical entities, common development tools. For several Python versions; HTML, Zip, Windows Help, text.

title: Python Recipes
desc: Collaborative website built by ActiveState and O'Reilly, hosts user contributions; collection of recipes.

title: Python SIGs
desc: Archives of current and past listserv discussions on a LOT of interesting topics. GREAT for researching problems.

title: Python Tutorial
desc: Introduction to Python, where to find it, how to install, and create a very simple script.

title: A Quick Tour of Python
desc: Short overview of some basics, for users with some programming knowledge.

title: TCC Publications: Programming Languages
desc: Python language quick reference (28 pp),  Tkinter reference (84 pp),  Python Imaging Library PIL quick reference (6 pp). Postscript and PDF formats available.

title: Tutorialized.com - Free Python tutorials
desc: A collection of Python tutorials from resources around the Internet.

title: Wikibooks Programming Python
desc: A tutorial for python on Wikibooks. It is editable by anyone.

title: Writing CGI Programs in Python
desc: Introduces using Python for CGI applications. Has database access examples. Several parts. [Developer Shed]

title: DjangoCon Europe
desc: Annual European Django community conference.

title: DjangoCon US
desc: Annual conference on the Django web framework.

title: GeoPython
desc: Conference for geographic information systems development using Python.

title: PyCon
desc: Listing of Python conferences.

title: PyData.org
desc: Conference and community for data scientists using Python.

title: PyOhio
desc: Free annual conference for Python programmers in Ohio.

title: SciPy Conferences
desc: Conferences organised by the SciPy community, for scientific computing.

title: Vancouver Python Day
desc: Vancouver-based Python mini-conference.

title: bridgekeeper
desc: A Perl to Python source code conversion service.

title: decompyle
desc: A service to decompile Python bytecode to readable Python source files.

title: Pythonware
desc: Developers of the PythonWorks IDE,  and useful modules such as the Python Imaging Library and  XML-RPC implementation.

title: ReportLab
desc: Authors of PDFgen, for generating professionally formatted printable documents on the fly.

title: Xellsoft
desc: Specialize in Python programming technology and object oriented databases, develop custom software and offer consulting in the area of internet, data communication, technical and scientific programming.

title: Core Python Programming
desc: By Wesley J. Chun; Prentice Hall PTR, 2001, ISBN 0130260363. For experienced developers to improve extant skills; professional level examples. Starts by introducing syntax, objects, error handling, functions, classes, built-ins. [Prentice Hall]

title: Data Structures and Algorithms with Object-Oriented Design Patterns in Python
desc:
The primary goal of this book is to promote object-oriented design using Python and to illustrate the use of the emerging object-oriented design patterns.
A secondary goal of the book is to present mathematical tools just in time. Analysis techniques and proofs are presented as needed and in the proper context.

title: Dive Into Python 3
desc: By Mark Pilgrim, Guide to Python 3  and its differences from Python 2. Each chapter starts with a real code sample and explains it fully. Has a comprehensive appendix of all the syntactic and semantic changes in Python 3

title: Foundations of Python Network Programming
desc: This book covers a wide range of topics. From raw TCP and UDP to encryption with TSL, and then to HTTP, SMTP, POP, IMAP, and ssh. It gives you a good understanding of each field and how to do everything on the network with Python.

title: Free Python books
desc: Free Python books and tutorials.

title: FreeTechBooks: Python Scripting Language
desc: Annotated list of free online books on Python scripting language. Topics range from beginner to advanced.

title: How to Think Like a Computer Scientist: Learning with Python
desc: By Allen B. Downey, Jeffrey Elkner, Chris Meyers; Green Tea Press, 2002, ISBN 0971677506. Teaches general principles of programming, via Python as subject language. Thorough, in-depth approach to many basic and intermediate programming topics. Full text online and downloads: HTML, PDF, PS, LaTeX. [Free, Green Tea Press]

title: An Introduction to Python
desc: By Guido van Rossum, Fred L. Drake, Jr.; Network Theory Ltd., 2003, ISBN 0954161769. Printed edition of official tutorial, for v2.x, from Python.org. [Network Theory, online]

title: Learn to Program Using Python
desc: Book by Alan Gauld with full text online. Introduction for those learning programming basics: terminology, concepts, methods to write code. Assumes no prior knowledge but basic computer skills.

title: Making Use of Python
desc: By Rashi Gupta; John Wiley and Sons, 2002, ISBN 0471219754. Covers language basics, use for CGI scripting, GUI development, network programming; shows why it is one of more sophisticated of popular scripting languages. [Wiley]

title: Practical Python
desc: By Magnus Lie Hetland; Apress LP, 2002, ISBN 1590590066. Readable guide to ideas most vital to new users, from basics common to high level languages, to more specific aspects, to a series of 10 ever more complex programs. [Apress]

title: Pro Python System Administration
desc: By Rytis Sileika, ISBN13: 978-1-4302-2605-5, Uses real-world system administration examples like manage devices with SNMP and SOAP, build a distributed monitoring system, manage web applications and parse complex log files, monitor and manage MySQL databases.

title: Programming in Python 3 (Second Edition)
desc: A Complete Introduction to the Python 3.

title: Python 2.1 Bible
desc: By Dave Brueck, Stephen Tanner; John Wiley and Sons, 2001, ISBN 0764548077. Full coverage, clear explanations, hands-on examples, full language reference; shows step by step how to use components, assemble them, form full-featured programs. [John Wiley and Sons]

title: Python 3 Object Oriented Programming
desc: A step-by-step tutorial for OOP in Python 3, including discussion and examples of abstraction, encapsulation, information hiding, and raise, handle, define, and manipulate exceptions.

title: Python Language Reference Manual
desc: By Guido van Rossum, Fred L. Drake, Jr.; Network Theory Ltd., 2003, ISBN 0954161785. Printed edition of official language reference, for v2.x, from Python.org, describes syntax, built-in datatypes. [Network Theory, online]

title: Python Programming Patterns
desc: By Thomas W. Christopher; Prentice Hall PTR, 2002, ISBN 0130409561. Shows how to write large programs, introduces powerful design patterns that deliver high levels of robustness, scalability, reuse.

title: Python Programming with the Java Class Libraries: A Tutorial for Building Web and Enterprise Applications with Jython
desc: By Richard Hightower; Addison-Wesley, 2002, 0201616165. Begins with Python basics, many exercises, interactive sessions. Shows programming novices concepts and practical methods. Shows programming experts Python's abilities and ways to interface with Java APIs. [publisher website]

title: Python: Visual QuickStart Guide
desc: By Chris Fehily; Peachpit Press, 2002, ISBN 0201748843. Task-based, step-by-step visual reference guide, many screen shots, for courses in digital graphics; Web design, scripting, development; multimedia, page layout, office tools, operating systems. [Prentice Hall]

title: Sams Teach Yourself Python in 24 Hours
desc: By Ivan Van Laningham; Sams Publishing, 2000, ISBN 0672317354. Split into 24 hands-on, 1 hour lessons; steps needed to learn topic: syntax, language features, OO design and programming, GUIs (Tkinter), system administration, CGI. [Sams Publishing]

title: Text Processing in Python
desc: By David Mertz; Addison Wesley. Book in progress, full text, ASCII format. Asks for feedback. [author website, Gnosis Software, Inc.]

title: XML Processing with Python
desc: By Sean McGrath; Prentice Hall PTR, 2000, ISBN 0130211192, has CD-ROM. Methods to build XML applications fast, Python tutorial, DOM and SAX, new Pyxie open source XML processing library. [Prentice Hall PTR]

title: Charming Python
desc: Column by David Mertz, Gnosis Software, Inc. Over 20 articles on Python programming, many topics.

title: Developing GNOME Application with Python
desc: Set of articles written for beginners in Gnome programming and GNU/Linux.

title: An Interview with Guido van Rossum
desc: Python creator discusses features and future of the language. O'Reilly Media.

title: Mark Lutz's Python Advocacy Page
desc: Links to several old Python articles and reviews.

title: Python Enhancement Proposals (PEPs)
desc: Design documents providing information to the Python community, or describing a new feature for Python.

title: Python Programming Language
desc: Growing article, with links to many related topics. [Wikipedia]

title: Python Squeezes the Web
desc: A practical example of using Python to automate the crawl of web pages.

title: SOA and Web Services
desc: Several articles related to the development of web services with Python, written by Mike Olson and Uche Ogbuji, 2001-2004. IBM developerWorks.

title: Interview of Guido van Rossum
desc: Interview of the BDFL by the visitors of a French Linux news portal (the English version is included).

title: A Conversation with Guido van Rossum
desc: Python creator talks with Bill Venners about topics relevant to Python and its community; 6 part series, Artima Software.

title: Proper XML Output in Python
desc: Uche Ogbuji explores the intricacies of creating proper XML output in Python, including character set and encoding issues.

title: Python Persistence Management
desc: Using serialization to store Python objects.

title: A Tour of 4Suite
desc: In this installment of Python and XML, Uche Ogbuji provides a tour of the core XML processing facilities of 4Suite.

title: Make Python Run as Fast as C with Psyco
desc: Using psyco, the python specializing compiler.

title: Simplified Exception Identification in Python
desc: Using functions and exception pattern dictionaries to simplify error recovery.

title: Pick Up Some Python with This Script Walk-through
desc: An example conversion of a Perl script to Python.

title: Space Shuttle Engineers Use Python to Streamline Mission Design
desc: Description of a practical use of Python by NASA, with quotes of Robin Friedrich, USA's Senior Project Engineer.

title: Python: Yes, You Should Be Using It!
desc: Alex Martelli gives an overview of the possibilities offered by Python, along with samples allowing the newcomer to experience Python code. [Free registration required to view this article.]

title: Using Mix-ins with Python
desc: An explanation of the mix-in programming style as applied in Python.

title: Embedding Python in Multi-Threaded C/C++ Applications
desc: A Linux Magazine article featuring an overview of the C/C++ API, explaining how to extend and embed Python in a multi-thread context.

title: Why Python?
desc: Article by Eric Raymond where he explains reasons that led him to switch from Perl to Python.

title: Linux Journal Python Interview
desc: An Interview with Guido van Rossum. A conversation with the creator of Python about an effort to teach Python to non-computer science students.

title: config
desc: Module allows implement a hierarchical configuration scheme for Python applications.

title: ExpectPy
desc: An extension for a Python-feel to the Expect library. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: Grouch
desc: Web development related open source software packages developed by MEMS and Nanotechnology Exchange. [Open Source, Python license]

title: log4p
desc: The Logging Toolkit For Python, modeled after the Java toolkit log4j. [Open Source, IBM Public License]

title: mxBase package extensions for Python
desc: The eGenix.com mx Extensions for Python are a collection of professional quality Python software tools which enhance Python's usability in many important areas such as ODBC database connectivity, fast text processing, date/time processing and web site programming.

title: Orange
desc: A free, component-based, public domain data mining software, which includes a range of preprocessing, modelling and data exploration techniques. [Open Source, GPL]

title: Parallel Python
desc: Provides an open source module to allow parallel execution of code on systems with multiple processors and on clusters. Features list, documentation, download, code samples, and a discussion forum.

title: Sisyphus
desc: A module that simplifies running Python stuff as cron jobs. [Open Source, Python license]

title: The Snack Sound Toolkit
desc: Module for basic sound handling (sound card and disk I/O); includes primitives for sound visualization, e.g. waveforms and spectrograms. [Open Source, GPL]

title: txObject ATK
desc: Contains the following parts: Object Library, IO/Timers, Threads, Inter-Process/Distributed Communication. [Open Source, GPL]

title: CPython
desc: The original implementation of Python, written in C.

title: IronPython
desc: A fast Python implementation for .NET and Mono.

title: Jython
desc: A 100 % Pure Java implementation of the Python language.

title: Python for .NET
desc: Package gives nearly seamless integration with .NET Common Language Runtime: CLR. Strong scripting tool, allows scripting or building full programs in Python, using .NET services and components coded in any language targeting CLR: Managed C++, C#, VB, JScript.

title: Stackless Python
desc: An experimental implementation that supports continuations, generators, microthreads, and coroutines.

title: Hypothesis
desc: Open source QuickCheck-style testing library. [Mozilla Public License]

title: Nose
desc: Popular unit testing tool. [LGPL]

title: Psyco
desc: Specializing (like a dynamic) compiler for Python, runs code 2-100 times faster, needs much memory; makes high level language faster. Descriptions, downloads (program, website), documents, news, links. [Open Source, MIT]

title: PyChecker
desc: A tool for finding common bugs in Python source code. It finds problems that are typically caught by a compiler for less dynamic languages, like C and C++. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: PyLint
desc: An extensible tool that checks if a module satisfies a given coding standard.

title: pytest
desc: Mature, open source unit testing library. [MIT License]

title: PyUnit
desc: An extensible unit testing framework for Python, based on Java's de facto standard JUnit framework.

title: twill
desc: A tool for Web application testing. It implements a simple scripting language that can be used interactively or from scripts; this language contains commands for browsing the Web, filling out forms, and asserting various conditions.

title: Boa Constructor
desc: A Python IDE that includes a GUI builder for wxPython. [Open Source, GPL]

title: Eric
desc: A Python IDE written in PyQt using the QScintilla editor widget. [Open Source, GPL]

title: Komodo IDE
desc: Text editor for dynamic programming languages, offering advanced support for Perl, PHP, JavaScript, Python, Tcl, and XSLT. Based on Scintilla and Mozilla. [Open Source]

title: Stani's Python Editor (SPE)
desc: A full-featured Python IDE and ships with Python Debugger (rpdb2), wxGlade (gui designer), PyChecker(source code doctor), Kiki(regex console) and Blender(3d) support. [Open source, GPL]

title: Wing IDE
desc: A powerful development environment for the Python programming language. [Commercial]

title: VisualWX
desc: A wxPython GUI designer for Windows. [Freeware]

title: XRCed
desc: A simple resource editor for wxWindows/wxPython GUI development which supports creating and editing files in XRC format. It is written in Python and uses wxPython GUI toolkit. [Open source, BSD license]

title: Boost.Python
desc: A C++ library which enables seamless interoperability between C++ and the Python programming language.

title: F2PY
desc: A Fortran to Python Interface Generator. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: Java-Python Extension
desc: A seamless, complete, and efficient integration of Java and standard Python (C Python). JPE provides Java access to Python's native extension, and Java's Swing to Python developers. [Open Source, MPL]

title: PyObjC
desc: Provides a bridge between the Python and Objective-C programming languages. [Open Source, MIT license]

title: Pyrex
desc: A Python-like language for writing extension modules.

title: SIP
desc: A tool that makes it very easy to create Python bindings for C and C++ libraries.

title: SWIG (Simplified Wrapper and Interface Generator)
desc: A tool that easily allows a developer to wrap C/C++ functions for use with scripting languages. Currently supports Python, Perl, and Tcl.

title: Python Wiki: Web Frameworks for Python
desc: An overview of all current Python web frameworks, maintained on the official Python language website by its developer community. Provides a linked list of frameworks organized by popularity and framework scale - from full-stack to minimalist solutions.

title: Albatross
desc: A toolkit for stateful web applications, providing templating and session management. Code, documentation, wiki, news, discussion list, and company information. [Open Source, BSD-like; commercially supported]

title: Aquarium
desc: A compact web framework providing session management, its own server, and templating using Cheetah; code, documentation, and a tutorial are available. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: CherryPy
desc: An object-oriented HTTP framework in Python, with flexible configuration and extension. Provided are code, documentation, FAQ, wiki, news, a tutorial, and IRC. [Open Source, MIT]

title: Flask
desc: A lightweight Python web framework based on Werkzeug and Jinja 2. Code, documentation, and community links are provided.

title: Glashammer
desc: A web framework emphasizing simplicity, flexibility, and extensibility. Source code, documentation, bug tracking, and a mailing list are available.

title: Grok
desc: An agile web framework based on the Zope3 codebase.  Code, documentation, an e-mail list, and a wiki are available.

title: Guido von Rossum on Python Web Frameworks
desc: An article by the creator of the Python language entitled, "Please Teach me Web Frameworks for Python!"  Published in January 2006, with extensive commentary from the Python community.

title: Nagare
desc: A BSD-licensed open-source framework using Stackless Python, providing continuations and direct callbacks registration for advanced web applications. Documentation, source code, mailing list, and other support are available.

title: Pylons Project
desc: A lightweight framework that allows several database, templating, user interface, and dispatch options. Site includes documentation, FAQ, community wiki, and installation instructions. [Open Source]

title: Quixote
desc: A framework for developing web applications in Python. Available are a mailing list and lists of articles and applications. [Open Source, Python license]

title: SkunkWeb Python Web Application Server
desc: An extensible application server, written in Python. Code, documentation, and a mailing list are available. [Open Source, GPL and BSD]

title: Turbogears
desc: A complete web framework integrating several Python projects: SQLObject, Cherrypy, Kid, and Mochikit. Code, documentation, examples, extensions, and related news are provided. [Open Source]

title: web.py
desc: A minimalist web framework written in Python. Available are code, examples, documentation, and discussion lists. [Open Source]

title: web2py
desc: An open source full-stack python web framework for scalable, secure and portable web applications. Code, documentation, videos, and support are available.

title: WebWare for Python
desc: A suite of software components for developing object-oriented, web-based applications. Code, documentation, and mailing lists. [Open Source, Python license]

title: Airspeed
desc: A templating engine for Python that aims for a high level of compatibility with the Velocity library for Java. Code, documentation, and a project Trac are available. [Open Source, BSD]

title: Cheetah
desc: A Python-powered template engine and code generator. Code, code repository, documentation, and a mailing list are available. [Open Source, Python license]

title: ClearSilver
desc: A high performance HTML template system with internationalization support, usable from Python and other languages. Code, documentation, forums, and news are available. [Open Source]

title: Genshi
desc: A Python library to generate and process HTML, XML or other text content on the web.  Available are code and code examples, documentation, a tutorial, project Trac, and FAQ. [Open Source]

title: Jinja2
desc: Popular templating engine with inheritance and bytecode compilation. [BSD License]

title: Kid
desc: A simple template language for XML based vocabularies written in Python. Code, documentation, and project blog and trac are available. [Open Source, MIT]

title: Mako
desc: A non-XML, Python-based web templating solution that is the successor to Myghty.  Code, documentation, community links, and project Trac system are provided. [Open Source, MIT]

title: Myghty
desc: A Python-based web templating framework originally based on Perl's HTML::Mason; it has been superseded by Mako. Legacy code and documentation are available. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: Pystache
desc: Python implementation of cross-platform Mustache templating engine. [MIT License]

title: SimpleTAL
desc: A standalone implementation of Zope's template language. Code, documentation, and examples are available. [Open Source, MIT license]

title: Spyce - Python Server Pages
desc: A server-side language that supports efficient Python-based dynamic HTML generation. Code, documentation, and project blog are available.[Open Source, OSI-Approved]

title: ASPN Python Modules
desc: ActiveState Open Source Programming tools for Perl Python XML xslt scripting with free trials. Quality development tools for programmers systems administrators database administrators network administrators and webmasters

title: ASV for Python
desc: A platform independent Python module to input, manipulate and output 'simple' database storage file formats such as CSV (Comma Separated Value) and TSV (Tab Separated Value). Also includes examples for using the module.

title: CDDB audio CD track info access
desc: This package allows retrieving CDDB audio CD track info access through Python.  In essence, it's a combination of three modules to access the CDDB online database.  The included C extension module enables it to fetch track lengths under many popular Operating Systems with easy portability.

title: FastCGI wrapper
desc: Use Robin Dunn's fcgi.py from a multi-threaded Python program. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: The form module
desc: An (incompatible) alternative to the CGI module from the standard Python distribution. [Open Source, GPL]

title: A list of open-source HTTP proxies written in Python
desc: The function of this page is to make this searching and comparison process easier for Python programmers.

title: Rob Hooft's Python Modules
desc: The modules presented on this page are those that the author felt were most generally applicable to python users, out of those that he contributed for the Bruker Nonius KappaCCD.

title: Welman
desc: The web external link manager makes evident the external links embedded in the pages of a web site by inserting of a marker image just after the link text. The program can also check the status of each external link and set two different markers selected by the user: one for ok status and one for broken status. [Freeware]

title: xmlSiteMakerPy
desc: Describes XML/XSLT based tool for offline HTML site generation, with download and examples.

title: HappyDoc
desc: A tool for extracting documentation from Python source code.

title: Synopsis
desc: A general source code documentation tool.

title: Ansible
desc: Build automation, deployment and management tool. [General Public License]

title: cx_Freeze
desc: A set of utilities for freezing Python scripts into executables, available for Windows and many Unix variants.

title: Fabric
desc: Command line deployment tool for deployment and system administration. [BSD License]

title: py2app
desc: A distutils command that packages Python programs into stand-alone Mac applications. [MIT/PSF License]

title: py2exe
desc: A distutils extension to convert Python scripts into executable Windows programs.

title: PyInstaller
desc: A program that packages Python programs into stand-alone executables, under Windows, Linux and Irix.

title: Python
desc: Official site for the interpreted, interactive, object-oriented, extensible programming language. Includes news, documentation, free downloads, and developer information.

title: Python Meetup Day
desc: A free service that coordinates local Python developers meeting in person, every month on the second Thursday of the month.

title: pyrepl
desc: A replacement for readline for use from Python with better multi-line editing. [Open Source, Python-style]

title: libgmail
desc: Python binding for Google's Gmail service. [Open Source, GPL]

title: ASN.1 library for Python
desc: An ASN.1 types and codecs implementation. [Open Source, BSD]

title: cx_bsdiff
desc: A Python extension module for binary patching and diffing. [Open Source, BSD license]

title: ID3.py
desc: A simple Python module for retrieving and setting ID3 tags on MP3 compressed audio files through an object-oriented interface. [Open Source, GPL]

title: LZO
desc: Python bindings for the LZO real-time data compression library. [Open Source, GPL]

title: PyLZMA
desc: Platform independent Python bindings for the LZMA compression library. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: jaxml
desc: Module for quick generation of XML (and HTML) documents with a stream-based approach. [Open Source, GPL]

title: maki
desc: An attempt to glue together a simple, flexible framework that allows you to use XML, XSLT, Apache, and Python to serve web pages. [Open Source, GPL]

title: PIRXX
desc: A Python InteRface to Xerces and Xalan, integrating it into PyXML. [Open Source, Python license]

title: Pyana
desc: A extension module that allows Python programs to interface with the Apache Software Foundation's Xalan XSLT transformation engine. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: PySablot
desc: Python bindings for Sablotron (a XSLT library) providing a simple API for in-memory XSLT transformations or file-to-file transformation. [Open Source, GPL]

title: PyTREX
desc: A Python implementation of TREX, an XML schema language. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: pyxhtml
desc: A Python XHTML class can be used to programatically generate XHTML documents. [Open source, BSD license]

title: SIG for XML Processing in Python
desc: While Python includes basic XML processing capabilities, the goal of this SIG is to make Python become the premier language for XML processing. The SIG, through the mailing list and the PyXML project hosted on SourceForge, is helping to decide what software is required for this purpose, and coordinate its implementation and documentation.

title: wctpxml-python
desc: A Python module that uses WCTP to send XML forms over HTTP. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: XIST
desc: A DOM parser (built on top of SAX2) with a very simple and pythonesque tree API and conversion methods ("object-oriented XSL"), for example for creating HTML. [Open-Source, Python license]

title: xmlproc
desc: An XML parser written in Python. It is a nearly complete validating parser with SGML Open Catalogs and XCatalog 0.1 support, SAX drivers and additional utilities.

title: CSV importer/exporter
desc: Has heuristics for determining file format and an optional wxPython dialog. [Open Source, Python license]

title: CSV module for Python
desc: Module for fast reading of CVS files. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: EmPy
desc: A templating system for Python. [Open Source, GPL]

title: mxTextTools
desc: Fast Text Manipulation Tools for Python. [Open Source]

title: pyMifluz
desc: Python bindings for mifluz (C++ library to build and query a full text inverted index). [Open Source, GPL]

title: pyparsing
desc: A general parsing module for Python. Grammars are implemented directly in the client code using parsing objects, instead of externally, as with lex/yacc-type tools. Includes simple examples for parsing SQL, CORBA IDL, and 4-function math. [Open source, MIT License]

title: PyStemmer
desc: Provides stemmer functionality in Python for English, German, Norwegian, Italian, Dutch, Portuguese, French, Swedish. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: ServPDF
desc: A web based Microsoft Office to PDF Converter Server which is based on SPYCE (Python Server Pages) and uses COM Automation to convert Office documents to Postscript and PDF. [Freeware]

title: SimpleParse
desc: A parser generator for mxTextTools. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: SnoPy
desc: Python extension for SNOBOL Pattern Matching using the SNOBOL code from the GNAT Ada compiler. [Open Source, GPL]

title: SPARK
desc: Scanning, Parsing, and Rewriting Kit. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: The Biopython Project
desc: Freely available  Python tools for computational molecular biology.

title: Pmv, ADT and ViPEr
desc: Python software from the Molecular Graphics Lab (MGL) of the Scripps Research institute. [Free for non-commercial use]

title: pyCGNS
desc: Python interface for CGNS (data standard for computational fluid dynamics). [Open Source, GPL]

title: PyDaylight
desc: Turns the Daylight toolkit into a rapid application development system for chemical information by providing a full Python interface. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: asynchttp
desc: An asynchronous HTTP client library. [Open Source, Python license]

title: CDDB.py
desc: Modules to access the CDDB online database of audio CD track titles and information. [Open Source, GPL]

title: ftputil
desc: A high-level interface to the ftplib module with an interface like the modules os and os.path in the standard library. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: jabber.py
desc: A Python module for the jabber instant messaging protocol. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: paramiko
desc: A module for Python that implements the SSH2 protocol for secure (encrypted and authenticated) connections to remote machines. [Open source, LGPL]

title: PyDNS
desc: A module for looking up DNS entries with Python applications. [Open Source, Python license]

title: pylibnet
desc: Interface for the libnet packet assembly system. [Open Source, GPL]

title: Pylibpcap
desc: A Python module for the libpcap packet capture library. You can use it to write a custom packet sniffer. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: PyMETAR
desc: Downloads the weather report for a given NOAA station ID, decodes it and the provides easy access to all the data found in the report.

title: PySNMP
desc: A set of Python packages implementing SNMP entities. [Open source, BSD-like]

title: Python Network Library
desc: Dissects network packets, as returned from pylibpcap. [Open Source, GPL]

title: Python-LDAP
desc: An LDAP client API for Python. [Public Domain]

title: pyX10
desc: A set of Python modules for the XAL X10 Automation Library. [Open Source, GPL]

title: radius.py
desc: A pure Python RFC2138 compliant RADIUS authentication module. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: Twisted
desc: An extensive Python library for event-driven network programming. [Open Source, MIT/X]

title: FixedPoint.py
desc: Python code module for fixed point decimal calculations.

title: GMPY
desc: Provides multiprecision arithmetic functionality to Python programmers. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: MatPy
desc: Python package for numerical computation and plotting with a MatLab-like interface.

title: Multipack Home Page
desc: Collection of FORTRAN routines interfaced with NumPy. Provides   interactive data analysis environment comparative to MATLAB, Octave, Scilab, etc. built on Python.

title: mxDateTime
desc: Date and Time types for Python. [Open Source]

title: NURBS - Non Uniform Rational B-Splines
desc: NURBS algorithms in use for naval architecture.

title: PyGiNaC
desc: A Python interface to the C++ library GiNaC (an open framework for symbolic computation within the C++ programming language). [Open Source, LGPL]

title: pygsl
desc: A Python interface for the GNU scientific library. [Open Source, GPL/LGPL]

title: QuantLib
desc: A free/open-source library for quantitative finance. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: R/SPlus
desc: Python interface to the R system for statistical computing and graphics. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: ScientificPython
desc: A collection of Python modules that are useful for scientific computing. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: SciPy
desc: Open Source Library of Scientific Tools.  SciPy supplements the popular Numeric module, gathering a variety of high level science and engineering modules together as a single package. Within SciPy are modules for graphics and plotting, optimization, integration, special functions, signal and image processing, genetic algorithms, ODE solvers, and others. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: anygui
desc: The goal of this project is to create an easy-to-use, simple, and generic module for making graphical user interfaces in Python. [Open Source, MIT license]

title: The Dabo Framework
desc: A 3-tier, cross-platform application development framework, written in Python atop the wxPython GUI toolkit. [Open source, MIT license]

title: FXPy
desc: Provides an interface to the FOX GUI library. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: Pmw
desc: Python meta widgets is a toolkit for building high-level compound widgets in Python using the Tkinter module. [Open Source, MIT license]

title: PyGTK
desc: Python bindings for the GTK widget set. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: PyKDE
desc: Python bindings for the KDE desktop environment. [GPL]

title: PyQt
desc: Contains Python bindings for the Qt GUI toolkit. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: Python X Library
desc: Pure Python interface to X Window system. [Open Source, GPL]

title: PythonCard
desc: A software construction kit built in, and using, Python. Its purpose is to allow you to easily and quickly build graphical applications. [Open Source, Python license]

title: Tix
desc: The Tk Interface eXtension is a set of GUI components that enhance the appearance and functionality of your Tkinter applications. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: Tix Applications Framework
desc: Tixapps applications are a suite of development applications that run with Tk/Tcl or Python using the Tix widget set. Applications currently included are:  tixinspect - an inspector for Tix/Tk applications; tixdebug - a debugger to work with tixinspect; and  tixinfo - an information browser for GNU documentation.

title: Tkinter3000 Widget Construction Kit
desc: Tkinter3000 is a Widget Construction Kit that allows you to write new Tkinter widgets in  Python using Mixins. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: wxPython
desc: A popular cross-platform Python GUI toolkit for Windows and Unix with native look and feel on each platform. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: xdialog
desc: A wrapper for the Xdialog program that encapsulates the details of calling Xdialog and getting return values. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: Biggles
desc: A 2D scientific plotting package for Python, geared toward the production of publication-quality plots. [Open Source, GPL]

title: gdmodule
desc: Python support for GD graphics library. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: Gnuplot.py
desc: A Python interface to the gnuplot plotting program. [Open Source, GPL]

title: Lightflow Rendering Interface
desc: An object oriented programming interface to synthetic rendering, which provides a common environment and description language to treat light distribution in three dimensional spaces. Also provides a Python API to the renderer. Free for non-commercial use.

title: Matplotlib
desc: 2D plotting library which produces publication quality figures in a variety of hardcopy formats and interactive environments across platforms. Matplotlib can be used in python scripts, the python and ipython shell (ala MATLAB, or Mathematica), web application servers, and six graphical user interface toolkits.

title: The MayaVi Data Visualizer
desc: A free, easy to use scientific data visualizer. [Open Source, GPL]

title: Ming
desc: A C library for generating SWF ("Flash") format movies. Ming includes a Python wrapper for the library. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: PyChart
desc: A Python library for creating high quality Encapsulated Postscript, PDF, PNG, or SVG charts. [Open source, GPL]

title: Pygal
desc: A python SVG Charts Creator.

title: PyOpenGL
desc: The binding layer between Python and OpenGL. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: Python Computer Graphics Kit
desc: Modules for creating 3D computer graphics images, focusing on Pixar's RenderMan interface. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: Python TWAIN Module
desc: Provides an interface to the Microsoft Windows TWAIN sub-system. [Open Source, GPL]

title: PythonWare Image Library (PIL)
desc: Provides image processing functionality and supports many file formats. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: VideoCapture
desc: A Win32 Python Extension for Accessing Video Devices (e.g. a USB WebCam, a TV-Card, ...) [Open-Source, LGPL]

title: VPython
desc: A free, open-source module for producing real-time 3D scenes with Python. Includes a modified version of IDLE. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: Fast Python Xmlrpc Library
desc: Fast implementation of the xmlrpc spec for Python with support for both blocking and non-blocking clients and servers on Windows and POSIX platforms. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: omniORBpy
desc: The Python version of the OmniORB CORBA Object Request Broker. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: ORBit-Python
desc: Python bindings for the ORBit CORBA Object Request Broker. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: Python Web Services
desc: Sourceforge project that hosts the SOAP implementations SOAP.py and ZSI (Zolera SOAP Infrastructure). [Open Source, Python license]

title: Another Python SQLite Wrapper
desc: APSW is a thin wrapper over the SQLite 3 API. [Open Source, zlib/libpng license]

title: MetaKit for Python
desc: A Python interface to MetaKit. MetaKit is an embeddable database which runs on Unix, Windows, Macintosh, and other platforms. [Open-Source, MIT]

title: Metakit for Python (Mk4py)
desc: A lower-level API for the Metakit C++ core extension, and uses SCXX by Gordon McMillan as C++ glue interface. [X/MIT-style and commercial licenses]

title: mxBeeBase
desc: On-disk B+Tree Based Database Kit. [Open Source]

title: PDO
desc: Python Database Objects provides a convenient Object Oriented API for database access in Python.  PDO supports multiple RDBMS with the same API, and provides features not found in the DB-API spec, such as column access by name. [OPen source, BSD style license]

title: pSQL
desc: A wrapper above MySQLdb which renders MySQL databases as very comfortable pythonic objects.

title: pyBSDdb
desc: Python bindings for BerkeleyDB 3.x embeddable database. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: PyDO2
desc: An ORM (Object-Relational Mapper) database access library for Python. [Open Source, GPL]

title: Python Database Row Module
desc: This Python 2.2 module defines light-weight objects which allow very flexible access to a fixed number of positional and named attributes via several interfaces. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: Python SQL Database Access System
desc: A simple and consistent programming interface to SQL databases, in Python. [Open source,  Python Software Foundation License]

title: SQLAlchemy
desc: SQL toolkit and Object Relational Mapper that gives application developers the full power and flexibility of SQL. [Open Source, MIT license]

title: SQLObject
desc: An Object Relational Manager for providing an object interface to your database, with tables as classes, rows as instances, and columns as attributes. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: Advanced Encryption Suite
desc: Implementations of the SHA256, AES and several CSPRNGs in pure Python. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: auth-modules
desc: A module collection for password authentication purposes and user database management. [Open source]

title: CryptKit
desc: A Cryptographic Toolkit for Python, which, among others, provides access to the SHA256, AES and ellipcitic curves algorithms. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: Pisces
desc: Python implementation of the SPKI Certificate standard. [Open Source, Python License]

title: pyOpenSSL
desc: Python interface to the OpenSSL library. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: Python mcrypt wrapper
desc: Python-mcrypt is a Python interface to the mcrypt library, which provides a uniform interface to several symmetric encryption algorithms. [Open Source, LGPL]

title: Python OpenSSL Wrappers
desc: A set of wrappers for Python of the OpenSSL libraries. POW will provide a 'slim' interface which will still enable Python developers to fully utilise OpenSSL. [Open Source, BSD-like]

title: Free(code): Python Software
desc: A listing of software written in Python in the Free(code) appindex.
